data.title: Context menu in terminal
data.body:
#8222

Like other terminals (terminal, iTerm) I would expect that we have a context menu on right click in our integrated terminal.
Potential actions to have there would be copy / paste, new terminal window, close terminal window...

data.title: Replace: make it more obvious that you are in replace mode
data.body:
Refs: #8184

I find it currently hard to understand that the results list shows different matches when you have focus in replace and typed something. You show the preview of the operation. If we want to keep this concept, we should at least show the before and after in one line, e.g. you could strike through the old result and show the replacement right after. I would also use different colors for that.

Related: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/8302

data.title: Replace: Replace button should be outside of input field
data.body:
Refs: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/8184

I think this would make it easier to discover that you have to press the action to replace all. It also moves the design closer to the editor find widget:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/900690/16414909/c38fb556-3d3a-11e6-81ad-09603404c2f5.png)

data.title: Replace: action should only be enabled when something can be replaced
data.body:
Refs: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/8184

Currently it always seems to be enabled:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/900690/16414873/944ffa26-3d3a-11e6-923e-fb080b73f175.png)

data.title: Replace in search viewlet is hard to discover
data.body:
Refs: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/8184

I think what we have now is a good start but I fear that people will not find the affordance to bring search into replace mode:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/900690/16414775/fb54687a-3d39-11e6-9c0c-3cebd969d899.png)

We should look into alternatives how to design this experience.

For discoverability.

data.title: Emmet: error handler for read function
data.body:
Help to testing #8207 
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0-insiders
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro (build 10586.420)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create file with `css` syntax
2. Create selector with `backdround-image` property and fake URL value (for example, `http://test-28062016.com/`)
3. Run `Emmet: Encode\Decode data:URL image`

**Error**:

```
index.html:28 [uncaught exception]: Unable to read http://test-28062016.com/: Error: getaddrinfo ENOTFOUND test-28062016.com test-28062016.com:80
```

data.title: Deeper inspection when CTRL+hovering over imported symbols
data.body:
For example, I have this file:

```
import { Part } from "./parts"

/**
 * This class implements communications with the server back-end API.
 */
class EditorClient {
    renderPart(part: Part) : string {
        return '' // TODO
    }
}
```

If I CTRL+hover over `Part` in `renderPart`, what's display isn't information about the imported symbol `Part`, but rather the `import` statement itself, which is rather uninteresting.

The same is true for "Go to definition", which goes to the `import` statement at the top of the file, from where I have to then trace it back to the actual declaration in the file - again, not very useful.

The same is true for "Peek definition", which lets me peek at the `import` statement a few lines above - not helpful.

Finally, "Find all references" also doesn't do what you'd hope for - it just gives you a list of references to the local symbol in the current file, rather than references to the imported symbol.

I suspect this boils down to one issue - that imported symbols resolve as just the local symbol, rather than the imported symbol?

I think that there is no real use, for any of the mentioned features, for imported symbols - the local symbols are pretty uninteresting, and it would make a lot more sense to resolve them in advance, so that I don't have to manually drill through them?

I think that they should probably even resolve recursively - because it's quite common to collect a bunch of imports and re-exports for the sole purpose of collecting them; it's a common enough pattern, and in every case, what's interesting is the concrete resolved symbol at the end of that import chain - the local symbols are not very interesting.

Thoughts?

data.title: Terminal actions: hover description too long
data.body:
#8222

Hover over the terminal actions - notice the very long hover description.
Terminal: Create New Integrated Terminal
Terminal: Kill the Active terminal instance

Long names make sense in the command pallete but not when hovering over the actions.
I propose shorter and more consie names - as we use in the rest of vscode.

New Terminal
Kill Terminal

data.title: Emmet: error decoding DataURI without workspace
data.body:
Help to testing #8207 
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0-insiders
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro (build 10586.420)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create untitled file without workspace
2. Set `css` syntax
3. Create selector with `backdround-image` property and `https://avatars1.githubusercontent.com/u/7034281?v=3&s=460` value
4. Press `F1` and run `Emmet: Encode\Decode data:URL image`
5. Press `F1` and run `Emmet: Encode\Decode data:URL image`
6. Will show the file name input box

**Problem**: We cannot work with files outside the workspace.

data.title: Attaching the process gives different errors in different platforms
data.body:
#8196
- VSCode Version: Insiders
- OS Version: Windows

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open VSCode for a sample folder
2. Create a new launch config to pick a node process
3. Open VSCode for vscode-node-debug
4. Run Server in launch config
5. In Sample folder workspace, Run 'Attach a process'
6. Select the node process which is from vscode-node-debug

In Windows, I get an error that 
Attach to process: cannot enable debug mode for process 'id' (reason: Error: T) : Reason does not makes sense.

In Mac, I get a timeout error

May be it would be useful to provide some information or a link why this is not enabled.

data.title: Not possible to open command pallete from terminal by F1
data.body:
#8222

There is not way to open the command pallet from within the terminal using the F1 key.
This is especailly troublesome since some of the terminal commands are in the command pallete, so optimally I could F1 > focus next terminal...

I can open quick open from within the terminal by cmd + E, but F1 seems to be ignored

data.title: Problems: filter text could improve

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Refs: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/7601

I was initially confused by the filter text "Filter by type or text" because I did not make the connection from "type" to problem type.

I would make it more explicit: "Filter by problem type or text".

@weinand who is best in finding good wording :)

data.title: Multiple Problem Matchers on same task clears out each other
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Insiders

I have these problem matchers on watching build command. (First one matches on Tslint, second on forked type checker of typescript.)

``` JSON
"problemMatcher": [
    {
        "owner": "typescript",
        "fileLocation": "relative",
        "pattern": [
            {
                "regexp": "^(ERROR|WARNING) in (.+)$",
                "severity" : 1,
                "file": 2
            },
            {
                "regexp": "^\\[(\\d+), (\\d+)\\]: (.+)$",
                "line": 1,
                "column": 2,
                "message": 3,
                "loop": true
            }
        ],
        "watching": {
            "activeOnStart": false,
            "beginsPattern": "Time: \\d+ms",
            "endsPattern": "webpack: bundle is now VALID."
        }
    },
    {
        "owner": "typescript",
        "fileLocation": ["relative", "${workspaceRoot}"],
        "pattern": [
            {
                "regexp": "^\\[default\\] (.*\\.tsx?) (\\d+,\\d+):$",
                "file": 1,
                "line": 2,
                "column": 3
            },
            {
                "regexp": "(.*)$",
                "message": 1
            }
        ],
        "watching": {
            "activeOnStart": true,
            "beginsPattern": "^\\[default\\] Checking started in a separate process...$",
            "endsPattern": "^\\[default\\] Ok"
        }
    }
]
```

They work individually correctly, but when on array they clear each other out with output e.g.

```
Listening at http://localhost:3333. Please wait, I'm building things for you...
Time: 6247ms
WARNING in ./App/o2c.ts
[36, 38]: block is empty
[38, 41]: block is empty
[21, 30]: expected nospace before colon in index-signature

WARNING in ./App/Index.tsx
[2, 13]: unused variable: 'React'

WARNING in ./App/Utils/OpenIdClient.ts
[204, 57]: block is empty
[210, 28]: block is empty
[42, 5]: unused variable: 'AUTHORIZATION'
[48, 13]: unused variable: 'state'
[202, 22]: missing radix parameter
[213, 6]: missing semicolon

WARNING in ./App/Containers/Login.tsx
[29, 1]: exceeds maximum line length of 140

WARNING in ./App/Containers/Sample/WorkListing.tsx
[47, 1]: exceeds maximum line length of 140

webpack: bundle is now VALID.
[default] Checking started in a separate process...
[default] Ok, 1.035 sec.
```

Problem is that both problem matchers has different begin and end. Which they should, but because of that the second matcher can't find problems and clears out the errors of first matcher. I can see the warnings appearing in the list shortly, only to be cleared by second matcher.

P.S. workaround is to put same values in end and begin patterns, the values that span the whole output, in my case 

```
"beginsPattern": "Time: \\d+ms",
"endsPattern": "^\\[default\\] Ok"
```

But this is not a solution, since it makes writing problem matchers dependent on other matchers in the array.
